elements.content: Complexes of the functionalized ligand 3-(1H-benzotriazol-1-yl)­propaneamide (“BTPA”) with MnCl2, CoCl2, CuCl2, and CuBr2 have been prepared and structurally characterized. Because BTPA is an amphiphilic molecule, a remarkable separation between the polar amide groups and the nonpolar benzotriazolyl residues occurs in the crystal. While in the free ligand the molecules are linked together by N–H···O bridges, the crystal structures of the metal complexes arise from interplay between bridging metal coordination and hydrogen bonding. All compounds are aggregated to supramolecular layers in the crystal, what makes them interesting as models for organic–inorganic hybrid membranes.
elements.clean_text: Complexes of the functionalized ligand 3-(1H-benzotriazol-1-yl)propaneamide ("BTPA") with MnCl2, CoCl2, CuCl2, and CuBr2 have been prepared and structurally characterized. While in the free ligand the molecules are linked together by N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridges, the crystal structures of the metal complexes arise from interplay between bridging metal coordination and hydrogen bonding. All compounds are aggregated to supramolecular layers in the crystal, what makes them interesting as models for organic-inorganic hybrid membranes.

elements.content: The design of supramolecular assemblies of metal complexes continues to be an important area of research in the coordination chemistry of main-group, transition metals, and f-elements. Due to their controllable architectures and facile assembly from simple building blocks such functional materials have found a variety of practical applications including catalysis, luminescence, sensing, gas storage and purification, medicine, and materials science. Di- and tridentate pyrazolyl-based ligands have contributed a great deal toward the fundamental understanding of supramolecular self-assembly of metal complexes. Particularly notable among the huge variety of such ligands are Trofimenko’s poly­(pyrazolyl)­borates (“scorpionates”) and the poly­(pyrazolyl)­methane ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of supramolecular assemblies of metal complexes continues to be an important area of research in the coordination chemistry of main-group, transition metals, and f-elements. Due to their controllable architectures and facile assembly from simple building blocks such functional materials have found a variety of practical applications including catalysis, luminescence, sensing, gas storage and purification, medicine, and materials science. Di- and tridentate pyrazolyl-based ligands have contributed a great deal toward the fundamental understanding of supramolecular self-assembly of metal complexes. Particularly notable among the huge variety of such ligands are Trofimenko's poly(pyrazolyl)borates ("scorpionates") and the poly(pyrazolyl)methane ligands.

elements.content: In recent studies we reported the synthesis and supramolecular coordination chemistry of the simple functionalized pyrazolyl-based ligand 3-(pyrazol-1-yl)­propaneamide (a). This compound is easily available in one step through base-catalyzed Michael addition of pyrazole to acrylamide. In combination with first- and second-row transition metals, 3-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)­propaneamide allows the design of a variety of hydrogen-bonded supramolecular assemblies, including different chains, sheets, and three-dimensional arrays. As an additional advantage, the pyrazolylpropanamide ligand system can be easily modified either by attachment of substituents to the propaneamide backbone or by replacing the pyrazole ring by other N-heterocycles such as triazole. In this study we were interested in the structural influence of benzotriazolyl as a hydrophobic functional group, which should impart amphiphilic character to the ligand and form the basis of novel supramolecular assemblies. We report here the solid-state structures of 3-(1H-benzotriazol-1-yl)­propaneamide (1, BTPA; cf. b) and of first-row transition metal complexes derived thereof.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Microanalyses of the compounds were performed with a Leco CHNS 932 apparatus and by Galbraith Laboratories, Inc., Knoxville, TN, USA. Melting points were determined with a Büchi B-450 digital melting point apparatus. The IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Vertex 70 V spectrometer equipped with a diamond ATR unit between 4000 and 250 cm–1. The relative intensities of the absorption bands are given as strong (s), middle (m), weak (w), and shoulder (sh). NMR spectra of 1 were recorded in DMSO-d 6 at 23(2) °C, using a BRUKER DPX 400 spectrometer (1H, 400.1 MHz; 13C, 100.6 MHz). UV/vis reflectance spectra were measured in a range between 250 and 800 nm using an AGILENT CARY 90 UV/vis spectrometer equipped with a Video Barrelino (Harrick), employing BaSO4 as a white standard. The energies of the absorption edges were determined from the spectra using the Kubelka–Munk method, each supposing a direct allowed transition. The magnetic moments were determined with the Gouy method at 293 K, using the magnetic balance Johnson Matthey MSB MK I. Diamagnetic corrections have been applied as χmol corr = χmol – χmol M,dia – 2χmol X,dia – 2χmol BTPA,dia (M = Mn, Co, Cu; X = Cl, Br). The molar diamagnetic susceptibility of the BTPA ligand has been experimentally determined as χmol BTPA,dia = −1.1 × 10–4 emu/mol, and the values for the metal and halogen atoms were taken from the literature as χmol M,dia = −1.3 × 10–5 emu/mol, χmol Cl,dia = −2.3 × 10–5 emu/mol, and χmol Br,dia = −3.4 × 10–5 emu/mol.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Microanalyses of the compounds were performed with a Leco CHNS 932 apparatus and by Galbraith Laboratories, Inc., Knoxville, TN, USA. Melting points were determined with a Büchi B-450 digital melting point apparatus. The IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Vertex 70 V spectrometer equipped with a diamond ATR unit between 4000 and 250 cm-1. The relative intensities of the absorption bands are given as strong (s), middle (m), weak (w), and shoulder (sh). NMR spectra of 1 were recorded in DMSO-d 6 at 23(2) °C, using a BRUKER DPX 400 spectrometer (1H, 400.1 MHz; 13C, 100.6 MHz). UV/vis reflectance spectra were measured in a range between 250 and 800 nm using an AGILENT CARY 90 UV/vis spectrometer equipped with a Video Barrelino (Harrick), employing BaSO4 as a white standard. The energies of the absorption edges were determined from the spectra using the Kubelka-Munk method, each supposing a direct allowed transition. The magnetic moments were determined with the Gouy method at 293 K, using the magnetic balance Johnson Matthey MSB MK I. Diamagnetic corrections have been applied as χmol corr = χmol - χmol M,dia - 2χmol X,dia - 2χmol BTPA,dia (M = Mn, Co, Cu; X = Cl, Br). The molar diamagnetic susceptibility of the BTPA ligand has been experimentally determined as χmol BTPA,dia = -1.1 × 10-4 emu/mol, and the values for the metal and halogen atoms were taken from the literature as χmol M,dia = -1.3 × 10-5 emu/mol, χmol Cl,dia = -2.3 × 10-5 emu/mol, and χmol Br,dia = -3.4 × 10-5 emu/mol.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray intensity data of 1 and 3 were collected on a Xcalibur Atlas Nova system with mirror-focused Cu Kα radiation, and absorption correction was applied using the multiscan method. Single crystals of 2, 4, and 5 were measured on a STOE IPDS 2T diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, and a numerical absorption correction was applied on the intensity data. All structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-97) and refined by full matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELXL-2016/4. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this work have been deposited at the CCDC. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on quoting the depository numbers 1532563–1532567 ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Analysis

Single crystal X-ray intensity data of 1 and 3 were collected on a Xcalibur Atlas Nova system with mirror-focused Cu Kα radiation, and absorption correction was applied using the multiscan method. Single crystals of 2, 4, and 5 were measured on a STOE IPDS 2T diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation, and a numerical absorption correction was applied on the intensity data. All structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-97) and refined by full matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELXL-2016/4. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this work have been deposited at the CCDC. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on quoting the depository numbers 1532563-1532567 ().

The ligand BTPA (1) was obtained by Michael addition between acrylamide and 1H-benzotriazol, using trimethylbenzylammonium hydroxide in methanol (“Triton B″) as a basic catalyst (a). Metal complexes of the series [MX2(BTPA)2] (M = Mn, Co, Cu; X = Cl, Br; 2–5) are readily formed by treatment of an appropriate hydrated metal halogenide with the ligand 1 in absolute ethanol solution, employing triethylorthoformate as a dehydratization agent (b). Compounds 2–5, which were isolated in 49–81% yield, are moderately soluble in polar organic solvents such as ethanol and acetonitrile and melt above 100 °C without decomposition.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of the Compounds

The ligand BTPA (1) was obtained by Michael addition between acrylamide and 1H-benzotriazol, using trimethylbenzylammonium hydroxide in methanol ("Triton B") as a basic catalyst (a). Metal complexes of the series [MX2(BTPA)2] (M = Mn, Co, Cu; X = Cl, Br; 2-5) are readily formed by treatment of an appropriate hydrated metal halogenide with the ligand 1 in absolute ethanol solution, employing triethylorthoformate as a dehydratization agent (b). Compounds 2-5, which were isolated in 49-81% yield, are moderately soluble in polar organic solvents such as ethanol and acetonitrile and melt above 100 °C without decomposition.

elements.content: Single crystals of the free BTPA ligand 1 were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a chloroform solution. X-ray structure analysis revealed the presence of well-defined molecules in the solid state, where the asymmetric unit contains one formula unit (monoclinic, P21/c; ). The amide moiety as well as the benzotriazolyl group adopts a typical planar conformation, where both groups are almost orthogonal to each other (angle between O–C–N1 and N2–N3–N4–C4–C5 planes, 88.8° ()).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of BTPA and Related Metal Complexes

Single crystals of the free BTPA ligand 1 were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a chloroform solution. X-ray structure analysis revealed the presence of well-defined molecules in the solid state, where the asymmetric unit contains one formula unit (monoclinic, P21/c; ). The amide moiety as well as the benzotriazolyl group adopts a typical planar conformation, where both groups are almost orthogonal to each other (angle between O-C-N1 and N2-N3-N4-C4-C5 planes, 88.8° ()).

elements.content: Molecular structure of the benzotriazolyl propaneamide 1 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of the benzotriazolyl propaneamide 1 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: In 1, the molecules are aggregated by N–H···O bridges between the amide groups, while the benzotriazolyl moiety undergoes no hydrogen bonding. Both amide H atoms form a C(4)-type hydrogen bond with the carbonyl O atom of an adjacent molecule. Both N–H···O bonds are almost identical in length, with N···O distances of 294.0(5) and 295.4(5) pm, respectively. The bridge N1–H1···O leads to a one-dimensional substructure along the crystallographic b-axis and the linkage N1–H2···O to a one-dimensional substructure along the c-axis direction. The result is a supramolecular layer structure extending parallel to (1 0 0) (). The two-dimensional structure is characterized by R 4 2(8) and R 4 4(16) patterns at the binary level. While the polar amide groups are directed toward the center of the layer, the nonpolar benzotriazolyl groups are situated on the surface. Since the angle between adjacent benzotriazolyl groups within the layer is approximately 59°, the layer structure does not seem to be markedly supported by π-aryl interactions. The layers are apparently stacked together by undefined dispersion interactions, with a minimal C···C distance of 372.9(6) pm between the benzotriazolyl backbones (minimum H···H, approximately 299 pm). The supramolecular structure of 1 is therefore entirely different from those of the previously described pyrazolyl- and triazolyl-functionalized propaneamides. These feature distinct dimeric units formed by R 2 2(8)-type N–H···O bridges and additional aggregation through N–H···N bridges.
elements.clean_text: In 1, the molecules are aggregated by N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridges between the amide groups, while the benzotriazolyl moiety undergoes no hydrogen bonding. Both amide H atoms form a C(4)-type hydrogen bond with the carbonyl O atom of an adjacent molecule. Both N-H⋅⋅⋅O bonds are almost identical in length, with N⋅⋅⋅O distances of 294.0(5) and 295.4(5) pm, respectively. The bridge N1-H1⋅⋅⋅O leads to a one-dimensional substructure along the crystallographic b-axis and the linkage N1-H2⋅⋅⋅O to a one-dimensional substructure along the c-axis direction. The result is a supramolecular layer structure extending parallel to (1 0 0) (). The two-dimensional structure is characterized by R 4 2(8) and R 4 4(16) patterns at the binary level. While the polar amide groups are directed toward the center of the layer, the nonpolar benzotriazolyl groups are situated on the surface. Since the angle between adjacent benzotriazolyl groups within the layer is approximately 59°, the layer structure does not seem to be markedly supported by π-aryl interactions. The layers are apparently stacked together by undefined dispersion interactions, with a minimal C⋅⋅⋅C distance of 372.9(6) pm between the benzotriazolyl backbones (minimum H⋅⋅⋅H, approximately 299 pm). The supramolecular structure of 1 is therefore entirely different from those of the previously described pyrazolyl- and triazolyl-functionalized propaneamides. These feature distinct dimeric units formed by R 2 2(8)-type N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridges and additional aggregation through N-H⋅⋅⋅N bridges.

elements.content: X-ray quality single crystals of the metal complexes were obtained directly from the ethanol reaction solution (2, 4) or by slow evaporation of an acetonitrile solution (3, 5). The chlorido complexes 2–4 crystallize isotypic in the monoclinic space group P21/c. In these, the BTPA ligand is attached to two symmetry-equivalent metal atoms in a μ–κO:κN4-bridging mode (). The metal atom is located on an inversion center and therefore coordinated by two Cl atoms and four BTPA ligands in a highly symmetric OC-6–12 coordination (Cl–M–Cl, O–M–O, and N–M–N angles, each 180°). This configuration has frequently been observed for other MCl2 complexes with N-functionalized amide ligands, e.g., 3-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)­propaneamide and pyridine-4-acetamide. Different from the latter, in 2–4 this arrangement is likely supported by an S(6)-type intramolecular N–H···Cl bridge between the coordinated amide moiety and the coordinated Cl atom. Thus, the molecular structures of 2–4 differ considerably from those of the previously reported complexes with pyrazolyl- and triazolyl-functionalized propaneamide ligands, which possess a chelating κO,κN4-coordination or a monodentate κN-coordination, respectively. In the case of manganese­(II), a dimeric complex with μ-bridging amide O atoms has also been found. Regardless, both the M–O and the M–N distances in 2–4 are consistent with those observed in related amide complexes or complexes with N-heterocyclic ligands, respectively. Due to the decreasing metal atom radius, the M–N4 separation also decreases going from Mn to Co to Cu (). In contrast, while the M–O distances decrease from Mn (216.8(1) pm) to Co (208.6(1) pm), the Cu–O bonds in 4 are markedly longer at 237.4(2) pm. This reflects a strong Jahn–Teller distortion which can be expected for copper­(II) in the octahedral ligand field, and therefore the O atoms define the axial positions of a quadratic bipyramid.

The bridging coordination of the BTPA ligand in the crystal structures of 2–4 leads to C6N6M2O2 16-membered rings, which are interconnected to a polymeric chain structure by mutual M atoms. The chains are interconnected by a hydrogen bridge between remaining N–H and a Cl atom of an adjacent chain (unitary motif C(10)­[R 2 2(16)]), forming a supramolecular layer structure (). Both the intra- and the intermolecular hydrogen bonds are similar in length, with N···Cl distances around 320 pm in 2–4. As in the free ligand 1, the nonpolar benzotriazolyl groups define the surface of the layer, while the metal atoms are situated inside.

The chains are interconnected by a hydrogen bridge between remaining N-H and a Cl atom of an adjacent chain (unitary motif C(10)[R 2 2(16)]), forming a supramolecular layer structure (). Both the intra- and the intermolecular hydrogen bonds are similar in length, with N⋅⋅⋅Cl distances around 320 pm in 2-4. As in the free ligand 1, the nonpolar benzotriazolyl groups define the surface of the layer, while the metal atoms are situated inside.

Intramolecular.

Intermolecular.

Noncoordinated amide group.

The benzotriazolyl groups of two neighboring chains are tilted to each other about approximately 42°, leading to an “accordion” profile of the supramolecular layer. Different from the free ligand 1, this arrangement allows effective stacking of the layers through π–π-interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups, where the closest C···C contact is approximately 345 pm in 2–4 (). Aggregation of one-dimensional coordination polymers by N–H···Cl bridges have also been observed in, e.g., pyridine-4-acetamide complexes, where a three-dimensional supramolecular framework exists (N···Cl, 333.4(3) and 324.7(4) pm). π–π-stacking is reported for numerous other coordination polymers with benzotriazole derived ligands.
elements.clean_text: The benzotriazolyl groups of two neighboring chains are tilted to each other about approximately 42°, leading to an "accordion" profile of the supramolecular layer. Different from the free ligand 1, this arrangement allows effective stacking of the layers through π-π-interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups, where the closest C⋅⋅⋅C contact is approximately 345 pm in 2-4 (). Aggregation of one-dimensional coordination polymers by N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl bridges have also been observed in, e.g., pyridine-4-acetamide complexes, where a three-dimensional supramolecular framework exists (N⋅⋅⋅Cl, 333.4(3) and 324.7(4) pm). π-π-stacking is reported for numerous other coordination polymers with benzotriazole derived ligands.

elements.content: Surprisingly, the structure of the copper­(II) bromide complex 5 is different from those described above, containing two types of coordination of the BTPA ligands (). One ligand is attached to two symmetry-related Cu atoms in a μ–κO,κN4-bridging mode as in 2–4. The other ligand is only κN4-coordinated with the amide O atom being uncoordinated. As a result, the copper atom displays a trigonal-bipyramidal coordination, where the two benzotriazolyl moieties define the axial positions (configuration index TBPY-5-33). The facile switch between the coordination numbers six and five is typical for copper­(II), and numerous five-coordinated complexes with nitrogen ligands occupying the axial sites have been described. As in 2–4, the neighboring coordination of an amide moiety and a halogenide ligand is probably supported by a S(6)-type intramolecular N1–H1···Br2 bridge (N1···Br2, 346(1) pm). Two CuBr2L fragments are consequently connected to a dimeric complex, featuring a centrosymmetric C6Cu2N6O2 16-membered ring just like in 2–4.

The facile switch between the coordination numbers six and five is typical for copper(II), and numerous five-coordinated complexes with nitrogen ligands occupying the axial sites have been described.  As in 2-4, the neighboring coordination of an amide moiety and a halogenide ligand is probably supported by a S(6)-type intramolecular N1-H1⋅⋅⋅Br2 bridge (N1⋅⋅⋅Br2, 346(1) pm). Two CuBr2L fragments are consequently connected to a dimeric complex, featuring a centrosymmetric C6Cu2N6O2 16-membered ring just like in 2-4.

elements.content: In 5, the dimeric molecules are interconnected by an assembly of various hydrogen bonds. First, the noncoordinated amide O atom, O2, undergoes supramolecular aggregation by a N1–H2···O2 bridge with the unitary motif C(16)­[R 2 2(24)]. The result is a ribbon-like substructure of alternating C6Cu2N6O2 and C8H2Cu2N8O4 rings, extending along the face-diagonal between the crystallographic a- and b-axes (). With an N1···O2 distance of 283.0(7) pm, the N–H···O bonds in 5 are stronger than in the free ligand 1 (). Moreover, the one-dimensional substructures are interconnected by two types of weaker hydrogen bonds of the noncoordinated amide group: (a) N5–H11···Br1 bridges (N5···Br1 351(1) pm), unitary motif C(18)­[R 2 2(20)], and (b) N5–H12···N3 bridges (N5···N3 336(1) pm), unitary motif C(11)­[R 2 2(30)]. The result is a supramolecular layer that extends parallel to (0 0 1). The architecture of the layer resembles that in 1–4, with the polar amide groups in the center and the nonpolar benzotriazolyl backbones defining the surfaces (). The closest C···C contact between the layers is 346(1) pm and therefore virtually identical with that in 2–4. However, the benzotriazolyl groups are not orientated correctly for well-defined π–π stacking.

elements.content: Supporting the X-ray structural models of the complexes 2–5, the compounds were also characterized by IR spectroscopy, UV/vis reflectance spectroscopy, and magnetic measurements. The IR spectrum of BTPA (1; ) shows the two very characteristic amide bands at 1644 cm–1 (ν­(CO)) and 1620 cm–1 (δ­(NH2)). In complexes 2–4, the ν­(CO) band is shifted to approximately 1660 cm–1 due to the absence of strong N–H···O bridges, which corresponds to the value observed for nonassociated amides. Accordingly, the spectrum of compound 5 displays two ν­(CO) bands at 1652 and 1683 cm–1, representing both metal-coordinated and hydrogen-bridged amide groups. Compared to 1, the δ­(NH2) band in 2–5 is shifted about 20–50 cm–1 to lower energies. The benzotriazolyl moiety gives rise to numerous ring deformation bands between 1500 and 990 cm–1, and to a very strong CH out-of-plane deformations band around 740 cm–1. ν­(M-O), ν­(M-N), and ν­(M-Cl) bands could not be assigned unambiguously.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Characterization and Magnetic Moments

Supporting the X-ray structural models of the complexes 2-5, the compounds were also characterized by IR spectroscopy, UV/vis reflectance spectroscopy, and magnetic measurements. The IR spectrum of BTPA (1; ) shows the two very characteristic amide bands at 1644 cm-1 (ν(CO)) and 1620 cm-1 (δ(NH2)). In complexes 2-4, the ν(CO) band is shifted to approximately 1660 cm-1 due to the absence of strong N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridges, which corresponds to the value observed for nonassociated amides. Accordingly, the spectrum of compound 5 displays two ν(CO) bands at 1652 and 1683 cm-1, representing both metal-coordinated and hydrogen-bridged amide groups. Compared to 1, the δ(NH2) band in 2-5 is shifted about 20-50 cm-1 to lower energies. The benzotriazolyl moiety gives rise to numerous ring deformation bands between 1500 and 990 cm-1, and to a very strong CH out-of-plane deformations band around 740 cm-1. ν(M-O), ν(M-N), and ν(M-Cl) bands could not be assigned unambiguously.

elements.content:
Characteristic IR Bands of the BTPA Ligand in <bold>1</bold>–<bold>5</bold>

Out of plane.

Noncoordinated.

Coordinated.

The UV/vis spectrum of 1 displays a sharp absorption edge at 310(2) nm or 4.00(3) eV, which corresponds to π transitions of the benzotriazolyl moiety and is similar to that of the parent benzotriazole. In complexes 2–5, this edge is slightly red-shifted to 315(2)–320(2) nm (). In each compound 1–5, contributions of the amide group have not been observed since they are expected below 250 nm and are therefore hidden by the benzotriazolyl absorption. Likewise, the weak metal centered d → d transitions in the visible spectra of 2–5 are not detected.

In each compound 1-5, contributions of the amide group have not been observed since they are expected below 250 nm and are therefore hidden by the benzotriazolyl absorption. Likewise, the weak metal centered d → d transitions in the visible spectra of 2-5 are not detected.

The magnetic moments observed for 2–5 are in the common range for coordination compounds of the appropriate metals and oxidation states. The value observed for the manganese complex 2 agrees well with the spin-only value for S = 5/2, and therefore the Mn atom adopts a typical high-spin configuration. In the cobalt complex 3, a high-spin configuration of the metal atom can be assumed, but the observed magnetic moment is considerably higher than the spin-only value for S = 3/2. In both copper complexes 4 and 5, the expected spin is S = 1/2. In the case of the trigonal-bipyramidal complex 5, the observed magnetic moment agrees well with the spin-only value of 1.73 μB, while the observed value is considerably higher for the distorted-octahedral complex 4. The large values observed for 3 and 4 can be attributed to a highly negative spin–orbital coupling constant, which is typical for the late first-row transition metals.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 3-(1H-benzotriazole-1-yl)­propaneamide (BTPA, 1) and four first-row transition metals thereof have been investigated. The benzotriazolyl moiety of the BTPA ligand adds new structural aspects to the supramolecular chemistry of N-heterocyclic functionalized amides, and it was shown that the structures arise from interplay of three building principles: (1) the coordination mode of the bifunctional BTPA ligand, (2) supramolecular aggregation through hydrogen bonding, and (3) supramolecular aggregation through π–π stacking interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The crystal structures of 3-(1H-benzotriazole-1-yl)propaneamide (BTPA, 1) and four first-row transition metals thereof have been investigated. The benzotriazolyl moiety of the BTPA ligand adds new structural aspects to the supramolecular chemistry of N-heterocyclic functionalized amides, and it was shown that the structures arise from interplay of three building principles: (1) the coordination mode of the bifunctional BTPA ligand, (2) supramolecular aggregation through hydrogen bonding, and (3) supramolecular aggregation through π-π stacking interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups.

elements.content: Regarding no. 1, it was shown that the BTPA ligand prefers a μ-bridging κO:κN-coordination rather than a chelating coordination, which has been most frequently observed for related pyrazolyl propaneamide ligands. This behavior might arise from the rigidity and the steric bulk of the benzotriazolyl groups, which perhaps can more efficiently stack in the case of a cyclic [(MX2)2(μ-BTPA)2] unit compared to a simple [(MX2)­(BTPA)2] chelate. Regarding the structural influence of hydrogen bonding no. 2, it has to be distinguished between “strong” and “weak” hydrogen bridges. The structure of the copper­(II) bromide complex 5 represents a competition between the metal atoms and the amide NH2 groups for the amide carbonyl moieties, as both metal coordinated and hydrogen bridged carbonyl groups are existent in this compound. Consequently, the coordinative M–O bonds and the N–H···O bridges seem to be of comparable strength. By contrast, M–N bonding with the benzotriazolyl group appears to be stronger than M–O coordination and is clearly preferred over N–H···N bridging, since the N atom in 3-position of the heterocycle is always attached to the metal center. Different from the strong N–H···O bonds, the N–H···X bonds (X = Cl, Br) observed in 2–5 have only a secondary structural impact, as they support existing structures (intramolecular S(6) bridges) or lead to a higher aggregation thereof (intermolecular C(n)­[R 2 2(m)] bridges). The same applies to π–π interactions no. 3. These have only a remarkable structural impact in 2–4 and are readily disturbed by N–H···O bridging, as the examples of compounds 1 and 5 illustrate. Consequently, the structural importance of the different interactions can be rated as follows: M − N coord . > M − O coord . ≈ N − H ··· O > N − H ··· X > π − π ⁡ stacking ≈ N − H ··· N Even though the structure of 5 is different from that of the isotypic complexes 2–4, the two-dimensional supramolecular architecture arises from the same building principles. In both cases, a one-dimensional “chain-of-rings” substructure is formed by strong interactions, namely covalent M–O linkage and/or N–H···O bridging. These are aggregated by weaker C(n)­[R 2 2(m)] N–H···X bridges (plus N–H···N bridges in 5) in a second direction (). The formation of two-dimensional arrays is supported by the amphiphilic character of the BTPA ligand, as the hydrophobic benzotriazolyl backbones always define the surface of the layer. The interaction between the layers strongly depends on the arrangement of the benzotriazolyl groups, which is again influenced by the strong binding interactions within the layer. Such a two-dimensional separation of polar and nonpolar portions of the molecule is of much importance for biological systems, and this behavior makes the substance class reported here interesting as models for inorganic–organic hybrid membranes.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of 1,2,4-benzotriazole (8.80 g, 74 mmol), acrylamide (5.00 g, 70 mmol) and Triton B (trimethylbenzylammonium hydroxide solution, 40% in methanol, 2 mL) was refluxed for 7 h. Upon cooling to room temperature a crystal cake formed, which was broken up by addition of 50 mL of diethyl ether. The solid was filtered off, dried in vacuo, and recrystallized from a minimal amount of hot THF. Yield: 12.9 g (93%). Mp 130 °C. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C9H10N4O, M = 190.21 g/mol: C, 56.8%; H, 5.30%; N, 29.4%. Found: C, 57.1%; H, 5.27%; N, 28.9%. IR: ν 3381m, 3354sh, 3327sh, 3189m, 3058w, 3048sh, 2989w, 2975w, 2949w, 2935w, 1644s, 1633sh, 1620s, 1588m, 1491m, 1443s, 1433sh, 1423s, 1394m, 1384w, 1368m, 1325s, 1302s, 1282m, 1264s, 1225s, 1161s, 1145m, 1136sh, 1115m, 1096s, 1053w, 997m, 992m, 933w, 919w, 847w, 818sh, 814m, 781s, 766m, 736s, 713s, 662sh, 645s, 630s, 606m, 578m, 569s, 551s, 506s, 463m, 433s, 352s, 305s, 252s cm–1. 1H NMR: 2.83 (t, 3 J H,H = 6.7 Hz, 2H; α-CH 2), 4.91 (t, 3 J H,H = 6.7 Hz, 2H; β-CH 2), 6.94 (s br, 1H; NH), 7.38 (m, 1H, 5-CH), 7.48 (s br, 1H; NH), 7.53 (m, 1H, 6-CH), 7.86 (m, 1H; 7-CH), 8.01 (m, 1H; 4-CH) ppm. 13C NMR: 35.0 (α-CH2), 43.9 (β-CH2), 110.9 (7-CH), 118.8 (4-CH), 124.0 (5-CH), 127.1 (6-CH), 133.0 (C–N–N), 145.1 (C–NN), 171.4 (CONH2) ppm.

Synthesis of the Metal Complexes <bold>2</bold>–<bold>5</bold>

To a solution of MnCl2·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O, CuCl2·2H2O, or CuBr2 (1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) and triethylorthoformate (4 mL), a warm solution of the amide 1 (0.38 g; 2 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was added and stirred for 1 h at 50 °C.

[MnCl<sub>2</sub>(BTPA)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

The solution was reduced to approximately 15 mL and then stored at 4 °C. A colorless, crystalline precipitate formed within several days, which was filtered off, washed with a few milliliters of cold ethanol, and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.41 g (81%). Mp 238 °C. Elem. Anal. Synthesis of 3-(1H-Benzotriazol-1-yl)propaneamide (1)

A mixture of 1,2,4-benzotriazole (8.80 g, 74 mmol), acrylamide (5.00 g, 70 mmol) and Triton B (trimethylbenzylammonium hydroxide solution, 40% in methanol, 2 mL) was refluxed for 7 h. Upon cooling to room temperature a crystal cake formed, which was broken up by addition of 50 mL of diethyl ether. The solid was filtered off, dried in vacuo, and recrystallized from a minimal amount of hot THF. Yield: 12.9 g (93%). Mp 130 °C. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C9H10N4O, M = 190.21 g/mol: C, 56.8%; H, 5.30%; N, 29.4%. Found: C, 57.1%; H, 5.27%; N, 28.9%. Synthesis of the Metal Complexes 2-5 

To a solution of MnCl2⋅6H2O, CoCl2⋅6H2O, CuCl2⋅2H2O, or CuBr2 (1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) and triethylorthoformate (4 mL), a warm solution of the amide 1 (0.38 g; 2 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was added and stirred for 1 h at 50 °C.

The solution was evaporated to dryness and the residue recrystallized from a minimum amount of boiling ethanol. The resulting green plates were filtered off, washed with a few milliliters of ethanol, and dried in vacuo, yielding a yellow-green crystalline powder. Yield: 0.25 g (49%). Mp 182 °C. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C18H20Cl2CuN8O2, M = 514.86 g/mol: C, 41.9%; H, 3.88%; N, 21.8%. Found: C, 41.7%; H, 3.83%; N, 21.2%. IR: ν 3332m, 3294w, 3233w, 3182w, 3130w, 3038w, 3023w, 2914w, 1644s, 1594w, 1574m, 1496w, 1457w, 1443sh, 1437m, 1422m, 1337, 1299w, 1279w, 1268m, 1231m, 1174m, 1153m, 1136w, 1121m, 1053w, 137m, 1006w, 948m, 898m, 845w, 786m, 760m, 743s, 644s, 596m, 541m, 523m, 485s, 433s, 363s, 321s, 304s, 278s, 266s, 255s cm–1.

[CuBr<sub>2</sub>(BTPA)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

The reaction mixture was worked up as described for 3, yielding a green crystalline solid. Yield: 0.45 g (74%). Mp 177 °C. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C18H20Br2CuN8O2, M = 603.78 g/mol: C, 35.8%; H, 3.31%; N, 18.6%. Found: C, 35.7%; H, 3.37%; N, 18.2%. IR: ν 3466m, 3350m, 3302m, 3181w, 3078w, 3070w, 3004w, 2960w, 2920w, 1683m, 1652s, 1595s, 1494w, 1454m, 1434s, 1419s, 1396w, 1368w, 1357w, 1329m, 1304m, 1287m, 1227s, 1213m, 1170s, 1149m, 957m, 928w, 847w, 817w, 777m, 769m, 757m, 738s, 719m, 709sh, 664m, 652m, 609m, 603s, 573m, 556s, 528sh, 518s, 505s, 478s, 435s, 395s, 383m, 328s, 315s, 288s cm–1.

The UV/vis spectrum of 1 displays a sharp absorption edge at 310(2) nm or 4.00(3) eV, which corresponds to π transitions of the benzotriazolyl moiety and is similar to that of the parent benzotriazole. In complexes 2–5, this edge is slightly red-shifted to 315(2)–320(2) nm (). In each compound 1–5, contributions of the amide group have not been observed since they are expected below 250 nm and are therefore hidden by the benzotriazolyl absorption. Likewise, the weak metal centered d → d transitions in the visible spectra of 2–5 are not detected.

Table 5. Levels of Aggregation in the Crystal Structures of 1–5

|       | direction 1                                      | direction 2                                      | direction 3                                      |
|-------|--------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|
| 1     | supramol. chain via C(4)-type N–H···O bridges     | supramol. chain via C(4)-type N–H···O bridges     | dispersion interactions                          |
| 2–4   | covalent chain of 16-membered rings              | C(10)[R<sub>2</sub><sup>2</sup>(16)])-type N–H···Cl bridges | π–π stacking                                      |
| 5     | covalent 16-membered rings linked by R<sub>2</sub><sup>2</sup>(24)-type N–H···O bridges | C(18)[R<sub>2</sub><sup>2</sup>(20)]-type N–H···Br bridges, supported by N–H···N bridges | weak π–π stacking/dispersion interactions |

cln_elements.content: Molecular structure of the benzotriazolyl propaneamide 1 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of the benzotriazolyl propaneamide 1 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level.

cln_elements.content: Supramolecular structure of BTPA (1) in the crystal, formed by N–H···O bridge bonding. The layer extends parallel to (1 0 0): (a) viewed in a projection on (0 1 0); (b) viewed in a projection on (1 0 0).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Supramolecular structure of BTPA (1) in the crystal, formed by N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridge bonding. The layer extends parallel to (1 0 0): (a) viewed in a projection on (0 1 0); (b) viewed in a projection on (1 0 0).

cln_elements.content: Molecular structure of [{MnCl2(BTPA)}∞] (2) in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level; H atoms attached to C atoms omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: ‘1 – x, −y, 2 – z”; “1 – x, −y, 1 – z”; “x, y, 1 + z”. The structures of [{CoCl2(BTPA)}∞] (3) and [{CuCl2(BTPA)}∞] (4) are isotypic.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Molecular structure of [{MnCl2(BTPA)}∞] (2) in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level; H atoms attached to C atoms omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: ‘1 - x, -y, 2 - z"; "1 - x, -y, 1 - z"; "x, y, 1 + z". The structures of [{CoCl2(BTPA)}∞] (3) and [{CuCl2(BTPA)}∞] (4) are isotypic.

cln_elements.content: Supramolecular layer structure of [{MCl2(BTPA)}∞]-type complexes (M = Mn, Co, Cu) at the example of the manganese­(II) complex 2: (a) viewed in a projection on (1 0 0); (b) in a projection on (0 1 0).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Supramolecular layer structure of [{MCl2(BTPA)}∞]-type complexes (M = Mn, Co, Cu) at the example of the manganese(II) complex 2: (a) viewed in a projection on (1 0 0); (b) in a projection on (0 1 0).

cln_elements.content: Stacking of the supramolecular [{MCl2(BTPA)}∞] layers as shown in Figure , by π–π-interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups (viewed in a projection on (0 0 1)).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Stacking of the supramolecular [{MCl2(BTPA)}∞] layers as shown in Figure  , by π-π-interactions between the benzotriazolyl groups (viewed in a projection on (0 0 1)).

cln_elements.content: Molecular structure of the copper­(II) bromide complex 2 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level, H atoms attached to C atoms omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: “–x, −y, 1 – z”.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Molecular structure of the copper(II) bromide complex 2 in the crystal. Displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level, H atoms attached to C atoms omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: "-x, -y, 1 - z".

cln_elements.content: Supramolecular substructure of compound 5, formed by intermolecular N–H···O bridge bonding. The infinite ribbon extends along the face-diagonal between the a- and b-axes.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Supramolecular substructure of compound 5, formed by intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O bridge bonding. The infinite ribbon extends along the face-diagonal between the a- and b-axes.

cln_elements.content: Aggregation of the one-dimensional substructure shown in Figure , by intermolecular N–H···Br and N–H···N bridges. The resulting supramolecular layer extends parallel to (0 0 1): (a) viewed in a projection on (1 1 0); (b) in a projection on (0 0 1).
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Aggregation of the one-dimensional substructure shown in Figure  , by intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅Br and N-H⋅⋅⋅N bridges. The resulting supramolecular layer extends parallel to (0 0 1): (a) viewed in a projection on (1 1 0); (b) in a projection on (0 0 1).
